puissant.sentence_1: Over the years of service, and quite to his surprise, he became a puissant advisor to the community.

intimation.sentence_1: At first the hostess tried intimation, praising the benefits of cutlery; when Cecil continued eating with his hands, the hostess told him to use a fork at dinner.

dovetail.sentence_1: Although Darwin's evolution and Mendel's genetics were developed in isolation from one another, they dovetail very well.
dovetail.meaning_1: verb: fit together tightly, as if by means of an interlocking joint

irrefutable.sentence_1: Scientists are searching for irrefutable evidence that some form of life existed on mars at some point in its history.
irrefutable.meaning_1: adjective: impossible to deny or disprove

hobble.sentence_1: Bad weather has hobbled rescue efforts, making it difficult for crews to find bodies in the wreckage.
hobble.meaning_1: verb: to hold back the progress of something

machinate.sentence_1: The rebels met at night in an abandoned barn to machinate.
machinate.meaning_1: verb: engage in plotting or enter into a conspiracy, swear together

cosset.sentence_1: The king and queen cosseted the young prince, giving him a prized miniature pony for his fifth birthday.

ossify.sentence_1: Even as a young man, Bob had some bias against poor people, but during his years in social services, his bad opinions ossified into unshiftable views.
ossify.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
ossify.meaning_1: verb: make rigid and set into a conventional pattern

imperious.sentence_1: Children are imperious with each other before they learn that earning someone's respect is better than demanding.
imperious.meaning_1: adjective: having or showing arrogant superiority to and disdain of those one views as unworthy

puerile.sentence_1: Helen enjoyed blowing soap bubbles, but Jim regarded this as puerile, totally unworthy of a woman with a Ph.D.
puerile.meaning_1: adjective: of or characteristic of a child; displaying or suggesting a lack of maturity

subterfuge.sentence_1: Finally deciding to abandon all subterfuge, Arthur revealed to Cindy everything about his secret affair over the past two years.
subterfuge.meaning_1: noun: something intended to misrepresent the true nature of an activity

dispensation.sentence_1: Since her father is a billionaire, she is given dispensation from many of the school's policies.
dispensation.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
dispensation.meaning_1: noun: an exemption from a rule or obligation

improvident.sentence_1: Marty was improvident, never putting money aside for the future but spending it on decorating the interior of his home.

celerity.sentence_1: We aim to respond to customers' questions with celerity and accuracy, with no longer than a 24 hour wait time.

hubris.sentence_1: Bill Clinton was criticized for his hubris, since he believed he could get away with anything once in the White House.

presentiment.sentence_1: On the night that Lincoln would be fatally shot, his wife had a presentiment about going to Ford's Theater, but Lincoln persuaded her that everything would be fine.
presentiment.meaning_1: noun: a feeling of evil to come

encumber.sentence_1: The costume encumbered all my movements and caused me to sweat profusely.

recrimination.sentence_1: The two brothers sat and cried, pointing fingers and making elaborate recriminations of the other's guilt

rarefied.sentence_1: Jack's vulgar jokes were not so successful in the rarefied environment of college professors.
rarefied.meaning_1: adjective: made more subtle or refined

crestfallen.sentence_1: I asked Maria on a date and she refused without a moment's thought; I was crestfallen.

patent.sentence_1: Since the book had been through no fewer than six proof runs, the staff was shocked to see such a patent spelling mistake remaining, right in the middle of the front cover!
patent.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

tempestuous.sentence_1: Chuck and Kathy had always been stable and agreeable people on their own, but when they got involved, it was a tempestuous relationship.
tempestuous.meaning_1: adjective: as if driven by turbulent or conflicting emotions; highly energetic and wildly changing or fluctuating

apposite.sentence_1: For a writer with such quick wit, Jonathan Swift has a rather apposite name.

corollary.sentence_1: A corollary of Hurricane Sandy, which ravaged the east coast of the U.S., is a push to build higher sea walls to protect against future hurricanes.
corollary.meaning_1: noun: a practical consequence that follows naturally

unviable.sentence_1: The plan was obviously unviable considering that it lead to complete environmental destruction in the river valley.
unviable.meaning_1: adjective: not able to work, survive, or succeed (also spelled inviable).

firebrand.sentence_1: Freddie is a firebrand: every time he walks into the office, he winds up at the center of heated argument.
firebrand.meaning_1: noun: someone who deliberately creates trouble

stalwart.sentence_1: Despite all the criticism directed at the President during this scandal, Lisa has remained his stalwart supporter.
stalwart.meaning_1: adjective: dependable; inured to fatigue or hardships

decry.sentence_1: The entire audience erupted in shouts and curses, decrying the penalty card issued by the referee.

flippant.sentence_1: Although Sam was trying to honor Mark's sense of humor, many found it quite flippant that he wore a comic nose and glasses mask to Mark's funeral.

untenable.sentence_1: With the combination of Kepler's brilliant theories and Galileo's telescopic observations, the old geocentric theory became untenable to most of the educated people in Europe.
untenable.meaning_1: adjective: (of theories etc) incapable of being defended or justified

peripatetic.sentence_1: Jim always preferred a peripatetic approach to discovering a city: he felt that he could see so many more details while walking.

inimitable.sentence_1: Mozart's music follows a clear pattern that, anyone could imitate, but his music gives an overall sense of effortlessness that is inimitable.

obstreperous.sentence_1: When the teacher asked the obstreperous student simply to bus his tray, the student threw the entire tray on the floor, shouted an epithet, and walked out.
obstreperous.meaning_1: adjective: noisily and stubbornly defiant; willfully difficult to control

spartan.sentence_1: After losing everything in a fire, Tim decided to live in spartan conditions, sleeping on the floor and owning as little furniture as a possible.
spartan.meaning_1: adjective: unsparing and uncompromising in discipline or judgment; practicing great self-denial

lacerate.sentence_1: The teacher was fired for lacerating a student who wrote a poor essay.
lacerate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
lacerate.meaning_1: verb: deeply hurt the feelings of; distress

nonchalant.sentence_1: The twenty-somethings at the coffee shop always irked Sheldon, especially the way in which they acted nonchalantly towards everything, not even caring when Sheldon once spilled his mocha on them.
nonchalant.meaning_1: adjective: coming across as uninterested or unconcerned; overly casual

surreptitious.sentence_1: Since his mom was a light sleeper, Timmy had to tiptoe surreptitiously through the entire house, careful to not make the floors creak, until he at last was able to enjoy his plunder: a box of chocolate chip cookies.
surreptitious.meaning_1: adjective: stealthy, taking pains not to be caught or detected

unpropitious.sentence_1: With only a bottle of water and a sandwich, the hikers faced an unpropitious task: ascending a huge mountain that took most two days to climb.
unpropitious.meaning_1: adjective: (of a circumstance) with little chance of success

crystallize.sentence_1: Only after fifteen minutes of brainstorming did Samantha's ideas for the essay crystallize.
crystallize.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
crystallize.meaning_1: verb: cause to take on a definite and clear shape

denouement.sentence_1: At the denouement of the movie, all questions were answered, and the true identity of the robber was revealed.
denouement.meaning_1: noun: the final resolution of the many strands of a literary or dramatic work; the outcome of a complex sequence of events

magisterial.sentence_1: Though she was only a third grade teacher, Ms. Martinet was magisterial in dealing with her class, lording over them like a queen.
magisterial.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
magisterial.meaning_1: adjective: offensively self-assured or given to exercising unwarranted power

invidious.sentence_1: At a time when many others in the office were about to be laid off, many considered Cheryl's fine clothes that day an invidious display.
invidious.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study

equitable.sentence_1: The equitable distribution of ice cream to a group of 5 year olds will ensure little to no fighting—at least until the ice cream is gone.
equitable.meaning_1: adjective: fair to all parties as dictated by reason and conscience

inure.sentence_1: Three years of Manhattan living has inured her to the sound of wailing sirens; she could probably sleep through the apocalypse.
inure.meaning_1: verb: to make accustomed to something unpleasant

asperity.sentence_1: The editor was known for his asperity, often sending severe letters of rejection to amateur writers.

inviolate.sentence_1: While the literary critic subjected most of the classics to the harshest reviews, he regarded Cervantes as inviolate, and had nothing but praise for him.

unflappable.sentence_1: The house shook and the ground quaked, but my dad was unflappable and comforted the family.
unflappable.meaning_1: adjective: not easily perturbed or excited or upset; marked by extreme calm and composure

immure.sentence_1: The modern supermarket experience makes many feel claustrophobic, as they are immured in walls upon walls of products.
immure.meaning_1: verb: to enclose, usually in walls

ribald.sentence_1: The speaker was famous for his ribald humor, but the high school principal asked him to keep the talk G-rated when he spoke to the student body.

impetuous.sentence_1: Herbert is rarely impetuous, but on the spur of the moment, he spent thousands of dollars on a motorcycle today.
impetuous.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation

incontrovertible.sentence_1: Unless you can provide incontrovertible evidence, I will remain skeptical.
incontrovertible.meaning_1: adjective: necessarily or demonstrably true; impossible to deny or disprove
